title: Russia's McDonald's Knockoff Isn't Original; Imitating the golden arches works until they actually show up in your country
text:
Some exist in the few places McDonald's hasn't planted its flag such as North Korea's Samtaesong (three big stars). A company specializing in tours of the hermit kingdom chose its words carefully when commenting on the quality of the burger chain: "Well, it is fair to say that Samtaesong probably wouldn't last long in a competitive and mature fast-food market â€¦"

Israel's MacDavid, which opened in the late 1970s, wasn't legally kosher according to the U.S. chain, which sued it for trademark infringement. It quickly dropped its Big Mac and has shriveled to a single outlet in Haifa since McDonald's arrived years later. Less is known about the fate of Kazakhstan's McDoner, which existed before McDonald's thundered into the former Soviet republic.

Try as they might, the consistent pattern has been the near extinction of local imitators once the American original arrives, but there is always hope. As MacDavid's owner David Magen defiantly told United Press International when facing down the fast food giant in court: "Did they invent the hamburger?"

Russia's McDonald's Knockoff Isn't Original
